text: I'm jay-bez McClelland I'm the group
leader in the electron physics group at
the National Institute of Standards and
Technology what we have here is a cold
atom ion source focused ion beam system
with lithium ion beams and it's the only
lithium ion beam system currently in the
world
it starts with a commercial system for
focused ion beams and that's over here
but what we've done is is heavily
modified it the lithium atoms start over
here in what looks like a baked potato
over there which is actually a lithium
oven it's when it gets heated the
lithium evaporates and makes a vapor and
then the atoms start streaming down this
tube here and we hit them with a laser
from the other side and when you scatter
photons off these lithium atoms as they
come down you can actually slow them
down and they get really really slow
they start out at a thousand meters per
second by the time they get in here
they're only going about 50 meters per
second and in here there's a trap and
that's got lasers from six different
directions in a magnetic field it's
called a magneto-optic trap which
basically catches those slowed atoms and
cools them down to really cold
temperatures a few hundred micro kelvins
above zero once they're in that trap we
bring another laser in which ionizes
them and then they get sucked by an
electric field down the tube into the
microscope they go through the
microscope they get focused they get
deflected and scanned and we can make
images with them one of the most
exciting applications that we're working
on right now is to use it to study
lithium-ion battery materials what we do
is we focus these lithium ions into tiny
spots and we aim them at different parts
of battery cathodes or battery anodes or
even the electrolytes that are inside
the battery they're often very
structured with all kinds of valleys and
nooks and crannies that are really
really small just a few nanometers in
size and if we can inject the ions into
different parts of them there's a hope
that we can help sort out how these
batteries work and how to make
better
